theories.card_other: Distance: Total path length traveled (scalar, always positive). Displacement: Straight-line distance from initial to final position (vector, can be zero).
Speed: Rate of change of distance (scalar, always positive). Velocity: Rate of change of displacement (vector, can be negative or zero).
Motion with constant velocity (zero acceleration). Equal displacements occur in equal time intervals. Velocity-time graph is horizontal line.
Motion with constant acceleration. Velocity changes uniformly with time. Velocity-time graph is straight line with non-zero slope.
Instantaneous: Value at a specific instant (slope of tangent on graph). Average: Total change divided by time interval (slope of secant line).
Motion under gravity alone with no air resistance. All objects fall with same acceleration g = 9.8 m/s² regardless of mass. Acceleration is always downward.
Law of Inertia: A body at rest remains at rest and a body in motion continues with constant velocity unless acted upon by an external net force. Defines inertial reference frames.
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to net force and inversely proportional to mass. F = ma. Defines force quantitatively.
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Forces always occur in pairs acting on different objects. Action-reaction pairs never cancel as they act on different bodies.
The tendency of a body to resist change in its state of rest or uniform motion. Mass is a measure of inertia - greater mass means greater inertia.
The quantity of motion possessed by a moving body. Vector quantity equal to product of mass and velocity. SI unit: kg·m/s or N·s.
Product of force and time interval during which it acts. Equals change in momentum. Vector quantity. SI unit: N·s. Large force for short time can produce same effect as small force for long time.
In an isolated system (no external forces), total momentum remains constant. Holds true for all types of collisions. Consequence of Newton's third law.
Collision in which both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved. Objects bounce off each other. No permanent deformation. Examples: collision between billiard balls, atoms.
Collision in which momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is not. Some KE converted to other forms (heat, sound, deformation). Objects may stick together (perfectly inelastic).
Motion of object launched at angle under gravity. Two independent components: horizontal (constant velocity) and vertical (uniformly accelerated). Path is parabola.
Maximum horizontal range occurs at 45° launch angle (in absence of air resistance). For complementary angles (θ and 90°-θ), range is same.
Force that opposes relative motion between surfaces in contact. Always acts parallel to surfaces. Static friction (at rest) is greater than kinetic friction (in motion).
Ratio of friction force to normal force. Dimensionless quantity. Symbol: μ. μs (static) > μk (kinetic). Depends on nature of surfaces, independent of area and mass.
